advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert puts forward network capabilities of Televideo systems.<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... If you want a personal computer that gives you professional performances, it's obvious that you have a lot of choices for today.<br> But there's only one with choices for tomorrow. Televideo ...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World, October 1983<br><br> Here are some answers:<br><font color="#666666"> "The BBC Microcomputers are the limousines of home computers. The graphics are probably the best' of any machine in this class. You are paying for Ii smart machine which would not disgrace the home of a professional."<br> <i>Video World., Feb. '83.</i><br><br> "Its design has given the BBC Micro an unrivalled potential for business, educational and serious home applications. It has been equipped to function as the heart of a system which can be expanded 10 suit its owner's need?"<br> <i>Which Micro & Software Review, Feb. '81</i><br><br> "The most attractive and exciting feature of the BBC Microcomputer is its enormous potential for expansion which will allow a higly expansive system to be built-up?"<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "They (the graphics) are tremendously exciting, and they are one of the features that make this machine stand out head and shoulders above everything else that is available in the market place at this time"<br> <i>Educalional Computing, May '82</i><br><br> "It is expandable and has a powerful BASIC. It has superb sound and graphics, the software is readily available and the price is righ"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Hampshire.</i><br><br> "The basics are easy to follow. My wife has developed a program for teaching our daughter French vocabulary. Our daughter uses it mainly for games and simple programming"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Co. Durham.</i><br><br> "It is a very powerful computer, My husband has written his own data base. I have been writing programs and programming games. Even the children have written small programs."<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Devon.</i><br><br> "No other computer can offer such ease of use when dealing with complex sound effects."<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "It isn't often a journalist can sit down to write about a computer with the certain knowledge that he has never seen a nicer machine."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, Dec. '82</i> "It has got huge potential. Besides playing the games, the whole family are learning basic programming."<br> <i>A BBC Micro owner from Staffordshire.</i><br><br> "Everything possible seems to have been done to ensure that this is not a 'dead end' machine.."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, July '82.</i></font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"access to the Forth power" <br><br> "with the Jupiter Ace, enjoy profesionnal experience of Forth"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> (FUNNY) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from a promotional brochure</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual floppy drive version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 100 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"compare!"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Sorry, you don't play with me"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This Eaca was the successor of the Genie I and Genie II. It was compatible with the Tandy TRS-80 Model 1.
The system was supplied with two operating systems, NEWDOS-80 version 2.0 (already available on Genie 1, Genie 2 or TRS-80 Model 1) and CP/M 2.2. Up to four 5'' or 8'' disk drives (640 KB each) could be connected.
When NEWDOS was loaded, the BASIC used was a RAM version of the TRS-80 Mod.1 ROM BASIC supplied by Microsoft. The video display showed 16 lines of 64 characters and the machine emulated a TRS-80 Model 1.
Under CP/M, the video display showed 25 lines of 80 Characters and the machine emulated a standard CP/M system.
The system featured a built-in real-time clock. Users could add an optional 288 x 640 pixels high-resolution graphics board (which seems to be exactly like the one of the Genie 1), a programmable-character interface or an external 5 MB hard-disk to run MP/M operating system.
computer.keyboard: Detachable full-stroke 86 keys with numeric keypad and 8 function keys
computer.name: VIDEO GENIE III / EG-3200
computer.peripherals: 288 x 640 pixels graphic board, programmable characters interface, 5 MB Hard-disk

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDE VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Genie III was about same size as a Tandy TRS-80 Model III.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Genie II uses a dual TEAC 5.25" DS DD floppy drive.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that a key was needed to switch the computer on.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A trap door allows to add / exchange system cards.<br> Only one Serial connector is available as standard.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Dual floppy disk drives<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Floppy disk controller card. Manages up to four 5.25 or 8" FDD<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 64 KB RAM card<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> CPU, video and I/O card<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Serial interface connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Internal video connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Switching power supply unit<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> CRT card <br><br> The inside was ventilated thanks to two large fans. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SYSTEM CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> CPU and I/O card. The Z80 CPU comes from SGS, Italy<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Floppy disk controller and real time clock card<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> ROM & RAM card. 32 x Motorola 4116 chips hold 64 KB RAM, a 2716 EPROM holds the system BIOS. Two additional ROM sockets are available.</blockquote>

computer.text: 16 lines x 64 char. / 24 lines x 80 char.
